awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Entropy in dynamics: connections with geometry, algebraic numbers, and bioscience
awd_abstract_narration:
Dynamics is the branch of mathematics that studies systems that evolve under time. From its origins in the late 19th century to today, the mathematical theory of dynamical systems has been inspired by problems in adjacent areas of mathematics (e.g. number theory, geometry, probability), and other natural sciences (e.g. celestial mechanics, statistical mechanics, population biology). This project belongs to that rich tradition, and focuses on deriving fundamental results for a variety of dynamical systems arising from geometry, number theory and applied settings. The common thread that unifies these topics is an 'entropic' approach to all the problems under consideration. The entropy of a dynamical system is a fundamental invariant which measures the complexity of its orbit structure. The three main research directions of the project are: (1) to establish uniqueness of measures of maximal entropy and equilibrium states in a variety of higher dimensional settings of interest to the dynamics and wider mathematical communities; (2) to give a number-theoretic description of all the possible entropies that can be achieved within certain natural classes of dynamical systems; (3) to use information-theoretic interpretations of entropy and related quantities to give insight to problems in mathematical bioscience. The project contains a substantial program of synergistic educational activities, including the development of an after-school math enrichment program for the Ohio State University Young Scholars Program. The program will develop fundamental mathematical skills for a talented population of students from under-represented groups taken from all the major urban areas of Ohio.

Part (1) of the project develops a novel approach to the theory of equilibrium states, focusing on implementation to non-uniformly and partially hyperbolic systems. The project develops novel techniques to overcome some of the traditional obstructions to developing an effective theory in these higher dimensional settings. The end goal is to use these results to derive numerous global statistical properties (central limit theorems, large deviations, etc.) for the systems within our framework. Motivating examples include geodesic flows in non-positive curvature, and the Teichmueller flow on the moduli space of quadratic differentials. Part (2) concerns the algebraic description of numbers arising as entropies of post-critically finite interval maps. A surprising relationship between the degree of the map and the algebraic properties of these numbers was identified experimentally in Thurston's final paper. A rigorous explanation of this phenomenon remains an open problem, which the PI has recast in terms of identifying zeros of certain complex functions. Part (3) investigates finitary versions of entropy, and related quantities, in the mathematical biosciences. The PI will use these quantities, interpreted as measures of complexity, as tools for detecting structure in large data sets, particularly those arising in genomic analysis and in the dynamics of biologically motivated networks.

por.por_cntn:
Dynamics is the branch of mathematics that studies systems that evolve under time. From its origins in the late 19th century to today, the mathematical theory of dynamical systems has been inspired by problems in adjacent areas of mathematics (e.g. number theory, geometry, probability), and other natural sciences (e.g. celestial mechanics, statistical mechanics, population biology). The project was inspired by this rich tradition, and focuses on deriving fundamental results for a variety of dynamical systems arising from geometry, number theory and applied settings.

One paradigm in dynamical systems is a dichotomy between the study of "high complexity" (positive entropy) dynamics, where small changes in initial conditions lead to widely different outcomes, and "low complexity" (zero entropy) dynamics, such as rotations, where the outcomes can be predicted and are "stable". Excellent theories describe these two distinct areas. The theory of hyperbolic dynamics gives a well-developed theory of smooth "high complexity" dynamics. There are also well-developed theories of "low complexity" dynamics. The interesting contemporary direction of research is to study what happens when both of these behaviors co-exist in the same dynamical system. Which type of behavior dominates? Under what conditions do we observe hyperbolic-type behavior despite the presence of non-hyperbolic orbits? A key natural testing ground for this kind of question is the class of geodesic flows on non-positive curvature manifolds, and this setting was a major focus of the proposal.

The findings constitute a major development in the area of thermodynamic formalism, which is a well-established subfield of ergodic theory and dynamical systems. A particular highlight of the research was a 2018 paper in the journal Geometric and Functional Analysis, building on a 2016 paper in the journal Advances in Mathematics, which together completely solved perhaps the most important goal of the project - creating a theory of equilibrium states for geodesic flows on non-positive curvature manifolds. In the case of non-positive curvature surfaces, we gave a complete description of when the "high complexity" dynamics present in the system dominates, and identified precisely the phase transition at which "low complexity" takes over.

The techniques developed are suitable for studying many other types of non-uniformly hyperbolic dynamical systems. Our methods have been implemented by several other teams of authors in the last few years. With this theory in place, we worked to derive finer dynamical properties of the equilibrium states we discovered, proving results on mixing and Central Limit Theorems. The new techniques required to do this have also been applied elsewhere already by other teams of mathematicians.

Another interesting direction of research was to relax the smoothness assumption which is built into the classical hyperbolic dynamics theory. We introduced a variety of new dynamical tools into the CAT(-1) setting, which is a non-smooth class of geodesic flows. In particular, the CAT(-1) class allows one to study objects with corners and hinges. This flexibility moves one far beyond the idealized world of smooth regularity assumptions.

The PI also proved results concerning algebraic properties of numbers associated to the entropies of certain interval maps, partially addressing a question of Thurston. The PI mentored a group of early career researchers on this problem at an American Mathematical Society Mathematics Research Community, which led to a series of fascinating papers about the "Thurston Master Teapot", combining numerical work with rigorous analysis.

Broader Impacts goals were also successfully accomplished. The PI gave many talks nationally and internationally to disseminate the work. The PI organized several scientific conferences and workshops.

The PI was heavily involved with mentoring, including a new mentoring program for graduate students at Ohio State, organizing a workshop on Graduate Advising in Mathematics, and setting up a series of Professional Development seminars.

Outreach goals were fulfilled through the PI?s work with the Ohio State Young Scholar's Program. YSP is a state-wide program for gifted high school students from low-income households and underrepresented groups.
